column2: P5JS - Changing colors with your mouse!
In part 3 of this activity, it's time to tie it all together and control the randomness with your mouse.
Yay! You're back, {{user_name}}! Let's get interactive!

First things first - let's get back to the p5.js code editor. You can load your previous sketch (if you saved it at http://editor.p5js.org ), or get back to where we left off: https://editor.p5js.org/madetohack/sketches/PwEfO7Hl
From our last sketch, when you hit play you should see a square that randomly flashes colors. But what if we wanted to see the square only when we click?
It turns out that p5.js has built-in ways to detect actions like "you clicked the mouse". They're called events, and it's really simple to use them!

The event we're going to use is mouseIsPressed(). You might recognize the form it uses - very similar to random() from last time, except it doesn't need any other information to do its job. This event lets you tell your code to do something when the mouse is clicked or not clicked.
Let's get going - Make a new line underneath stroke(r,g,b);. On that line, type if (mouseIsPressed == true) {

This line of code isn't like any other line we've used before - let's break it down. First, we're starting with the word if. That's a special word that tells p5.js that this line asks the program to make a decision - If the little bit of code in the parentheses ( () ) is true, then it will run the code inside the curly braces ( {} ). If it's false, that code won't run.

The decision we're asking p5.js to make is whether mouseIsPressed == true What's that mean? Well, mouseIsPressed detects if the mouse button is pressed or not. The == is the code version of is equal to, and true is, well, true! So this code is asking "is mouseIsPressed equal to true?". More simply, that translates to "is the mouse button pressed?"
This kind of statement is called a boolean statement - it can only be true ot false, nothing else. Very useful for a computer program!

Now, you might notice that there are some lines in your sketch highlighted in red. That's because we didn't close the if statement that we just created with an ending }. Like draw() and setup(), if statements need have a set of curly braces ( {} ) after them to mark the code they control.

Hmm, I wonder where we should put the closing curly brace ( } ) for this if statement? Oh, right - we want to control whether the rectangle draws or not... so let's surround our rect(... code! After the line with rect(... on it, create a new line and type }. All the red should go away, and you can press Play!
Cool, huh? I wonder what might happen if you replaced mouseIsPressed == true with mouseIsPressed == false?
Interesting! Try moving other code into the if statement - Maybe you can add another fill(... in there with a diffferent color!
Yow, you're really becoming a pro with p5.js. I can't wait to see what we make in the future! See you later!
